awd_titl_txt: CISE-MSI: RCBP-RF: S&CC: Building a Smart Mobility Network for the San Antonio Transit  to Improve Transit Service and Social Impact (SmartSAT)
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2).

Public transportation connects people to their jobs, schools, medical and recreational facilities, friends, and family. Public transportation users in most American cities have disproportionately lower incomes than commuters who use automobiles. San Antonio (SA), TX, follows this trend, with 67% of public transit users falling below the poverty line. Providing reliable and accessible public transit will benefit all transit users and, therefore, promote the upward mobility, health, and wellness of all San Antonians. To improve the reliability of transit information and the quality of the rider experience, many transit authorities have developed smartphone apps. The public demand for public transportation smartphone apps is increasing in many urban areas, particularly among people in lower income brackets who primarily access the internet through their smartphones. However, maintaining sustainable, high-quality service and information on these apps is challenging. This SmartSAT project will develop a customizable secure mobile app for SA public transit that provides users with enhanced, accurate information about transit service and enables data collection to evaluate the impact of poverty, race, and ethnicity on the experience of transit users. 

The resulting SmartSAT project will (1) provide riders real-time information of arrival times and bus capacity with limited seats available, (2) build an in feedback on-trip experiences, (3) utilize intelligent technology and conduct data-driven decision making when analyzing data, (4) provide reliable and accessible transit with convenient and equal access to get places, and (5) integrate SA community stakeholders into a future smart and connected city in the long run. Researchers and students from diverse disciplines (sociology, computer science, cyber security, & information science) will work collaboratively to achieve project success. The outcomes of this project will primarily benefit low-income SA residents, especially the large Hispanic population. SmartSAT will ultimately improve SA mobile network infrastructure and connect more workers to jobs and workforce training, more students to educational opportunities, and more residents to social and leisure activities. It can impact the lives of public transit users, specifically, minority communities and lower income earners who make up most transit users. The built network can serve as a transferal model for similar metropolitan areas in advancing the mobility of public transportation services supported by data-driven decisions using intelligent technologies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of the project is to build a secure smart app that provides users with enhanced, accurate information about transit services, to conduct research on arrival time accuracy and user privacy, and to enable data collection to evaluate the impact of poverty, race, and ethnicity on the experience of transit users.

SmartSAT, a customizable mobile app for San Antonio Transit, has been designed and developed to deliver essential services to transit users. With this, the study analyzed the features, usability, and performance of three serverless cloud computing platforms. The analysis was conducted with a containerized mobile application, SmartSAT, designed to track real-time bus locations for San Antonio public buses on specific routes and provide estimated arrival times for selected bus stops for this project. The study evaluated various system-related features, including service configuration, pricing, and memory and CPU capacity, along with performance metrics such as container latency, distance matrix API response time, and CPU utilization for each service. The findings provide valuable insights for selecting an appropriate serverless cloud service for similar containerized web applications. While they are practical, the results have implications for future research and development practices in serverless cloud computing.  To support the study's findings more applicably and objectively to other types of applications or broader contexts in serverless computing, a more thorough examination of factors affecting performance differences such as platform architecture, underlying infrastructure, and/or specific optimization in future studies could enhance the depth of analysis and generalization. 

The project achieved significant advancements in public transportation analytics, focusing on the San Antonio Transit System. Field studies and predictive modeling identified punctuality issues and optimization opportunities for bus routes. Key findings revealed consistent performance for some routes, with also delays noted on a few routes. Machine learning models, particularly Random Forest and Decision Trees, demonstrated robust performance in evaluating transit adherence. The outcomes emphasize the importance of data-driven strategies in improving urban mobility, aligning with broader goals of environmental sustainability and enhanced quality of life. Beyond academic contributions, the research influenced transportation planning, urban development, and public policy. It provided actionable insights to transit authorities, fostering strategic investments in infrastructure and operational improvements. By addressing societal challenges like accessibility and emissions reduction, the project underscores the transformative potential of technology and data analytics in shaping sustainable cities.

The social impact portion of the research found that the role of technologies such as SmartSAT app are crucial for Latinx communities in San Antonio because they provide the ability for riders to reduce time spent waiting for buses and missing buses. Survey respondents felt that these technologies were helpful and overwhelmingly noted that they would use these technologies in their planning of their bus use.  This illustrates that technology is crucial for transit for the predominantly Latinx and working-class respondents to access bus schedules and arrival/departure times. While we did not directly address the rider’s experiences with arrival times, we did find that the use of these technologies, in their opinions, would aid in making their commuting experiences better overall. This was illustrated with 81% noting that the technologies they use give them an accurate arrival/departure time.  This ultimately supports the relevance of Hypothesis in the lives of Latinx working class and poor communities in San Antonio. Their experiences with public transit and the accuracy of the arrival/departure times will have a significant impact on their quality of life. With over 80% of the respondents travel times taking 45 minutes or more, the accuracy of reporting arrivals/departures is crucial in their ability to arrive on time to their destinations such as work or appointments. Our concluding hypothesis ultimately is supported as the respondents did rely immensely on the reliability of the reporting from the existing apps/resources they used to schedule and use the VIA transit system in San Antonio. 

The privacy-preserving framework for efficient spatial nearest-neighbor search developed in this project significantly contributes to the intellectual merit of our work. The goal is to build a secure application that enhances the service, reliability, and accessibility of San Antonio Transit while collecting valuable data to inform future improvements and investments in transit services. In utilizing the Transit to query the best routes and serve the residents of San Antonio effectively, safeguarding sensitive data and protecting user privacy are critical concerns. The framework we developed addresses these challenges by concealing users' spatial data while ensuring convenience and equitable access to the application. This approach enables users to enjoy the best possible transit service without compromising their privacy.
